Title: Abbado Stravinsky, Shostakovich Gershwin
Description:
Berliner Philharmoniker 5 marzo 2000. Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra - Claudio Abbado - Winton Marsalis - Wayne Marshall Stravinsky: il Tango con chitarra acustica amplificata e musica a onde; il Ragtime per undici strumenti; il brevissimo Preludium for Jazzband; e lo Scherzo alla Russa per Ensemble di Jazz, tra fanfara e carillon. Poi il Tea for two di Vincent Youmans che nella trascrizione per orchestra di Sciostakovich diventa TahitiTrott; la Catfish Row da "Porgy and Bess" di Gershwin con una Summertime e sempre di Gershwin la Cuban Ouverture. Ultima parte non completa.
Questo è un upload su richiesta.

Title: Argerich | Abbado: Prokofiev - Piano Concerto No. 3 (1969, live)
Description:
Things have been very difficult for us all lately, haven't they? I've been a little unhappy with everything that is going on in my country and around the globe. My sadness somehow prevented me from doing things I like, which includes uploading stuff here on YouTube. Another thing that discouraged me from posting anything is the fact that some pages have been downloading material from my channel and uploading in their own channels, instagram accounts etc. 

Last Sunday, however, I was checking my archive and I came across this recording of the Prokofiev concerto that I simply love, so I thought of sharing it here. 
Argerich and Abbado had a wonderful creative partnership and whenever they shared the stage, it was a historic event. This performance of the 3rd Prokofiev concerto you are listening to was given two years after they recorded that legendary Deutsche Grammophon disc (featuring Liszt/Prokofiev concerti) and, in my opinion, is even more exhilarating than the one in that LP. Notice how the audience goes wild when they finish. I hope you all are doing good. Stay safe!
If you like this upload, share it with friends, so it can reach more people :)

Orchestre National de l´ORTF
Martha Argerich, piano
Claudio Abbado, conductor
1969, November 12th （Paris/live）

Sergei Prokofiev
Piano Concerto No. 3 in C major, Op. 26
00:00 – Andante – Allegro
09:13 – Tema con variazioni
18:46 – Allegro, ma non troppo

Title: Beethoven-BPO-Abbado - Carnegie, 2001
Description:
Here is a live concert from Carnegie Hall presented October 6, 2001 by the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra under the direction of Claudio Abbado.  In the program book for the evening concert, there was a statement from the orchestra dedicating its New York concerts and coming American tour to ''all those who suffered'' from the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11.  ''John F. Kennedy once said at a critical moment in Berlin's history, 'Ich bin ein Berliner,' '' the statement read in part. ''At this terrible moment, we are the ones who say with you, 'We are all New Yorkers.' ''  The originally scheduled program was changed to an all-Beethoven concert two weeks prior, when Abbado explained that he felt the works of Beethoven, a composer who was motivated by great ideals and believed strongly in liberty and freedom, were an appropriate musical statement in light of the tragic events of Sept. 11.

- Symphony No. 5 in C minor  0:00 
- Symphony No. 6 in F Major  37:05 
- encore: Egmont Overture  1:19:12

Title: Berlioz Symphonie Fantastique - London Symphony Orchestra - Claudio Abbado (Royal Albert Hall, 1983)
Description:
I was really not sure whether to post this recording, since there are already 2 recordings of the very same performance on YouTube already. I have however decided to make it available, since for me at least the sound quality on one of the existing recording unfortunately has significant problems and having compared with the other I still felt I preferred the sound of my own recording. I only hope this upload will serve the actual performance by Abbado and the LSO as well as possible, and my sincere apologies if this comes over in any way as being critical of another post since that is not my intention.

This performance was given as part of a BBC Promenade Concert on 1 September 1983 in the Royal Albert Hall, London

London Symphony Orchestra
conducted by
Claudio Abbado

Title: Bruckner 1 Philadelphia Abbado Feb 1971 Live
Description: A great performance of Bruckner’s funnest, sunniest symphony, let down by the sound at any dynamic greater than mf in the first movement. Adjustments are made on the fly so that by the scherzo it’s much improved. Philadelphia commercially recorded just symphonies 4, 5, and 7 (and the Te Deum) during the Ormandy years, and 3, 4, and 5 with Sawallisch. After hearing his 7 and 9 live, I hope Yannick plans to add to these. Abbado is interviewed at the intermission feature that precedes the symphony.

Title: Bruckner Symphony No. 9 D minor ⅠClaudio Abbado Berliner Philharmoniker
Description:
Bruckner Symphony No. 9 D minor ⅠClaudio Abbado Berliner Philharmoniker
 1997,5,17-18
【おぉたむすねィくAutumnsnake】廃墟探検部門　　「そして、海へ」編集部　大西輝明、勅使河原賢明、松岡明芳

http://blogs.yahoo.co.jp/autumn_snake_1995/folder/873380.htm
Anton Bruckner's Symphony No. 9 in D minor is the last Symphony upon which he worked, leaving the last movement incomplete at the time of his death in 1896. The symphony was premiered under Ferdinand Löwe in Vienna in 1903, after Bruckner's death. Bruckner dedicated this symphony "to the beloved God" (in German, "dem lieben Gott").

(While it may seem logical to call this work "Symphony in D minor, opus posthumous," that usually refers to the Symphony No. 0 in D minor).


The symphony has four movements, although the fourth is incomplete and fragmentary. Of this finale, it seems that much material in full score may have been lost very soon after the composer's death, and therefore large sections exist only in two-stave sketch format. The placement of the Scherzo second, and the key, D minor, are only two elements this work has in common with Beethoven's Ninth Symphony.

The symphony is so often performed without any sort of finale that some authors describe "the form of this symphony [as] ... a massive arch, two slow movements straddling an energetic Scherzo."[1]

The score calls for three each of flutes, oboes, clarinets in B-flat and A (Adagio only), bassoons, with eight horns (5.--8. Hrn. doubling on Wagner tubas), three trumpets in F, three trombones, contrabass tuba, timpani and strings.

Title: Claude Debussy: La Mer (Lucerne Festival Orchestra, Claudio Abbado)
Description:
Founding Concert of the Lucerne Festival Orchestra
Recorded live at the Lucerne Festival, Summer 2003
Concert Hall of the Culture- and Convention Center Lucerne, 14. August 2003

Lucerne Festival Orchestra
Claudio Abbado - conductor

Click here to compare Claude Debussy's interpretation with Esa-Pekka Salonen's as conductors: https://youtu.be/kxEMgHGrAPM

La Mer - Trois esquisses symphoniques
The Sea - three symphonic sketches
Das Meer - drei symphonische Skizzen

0:00 I. De l'aube à midi sur la mer. Très lent (8:35)
From Dawn to Midday at Sea
Vom Morgen bis zum Mittag auf dem Meer

8:31 II. Jeux de vagues. Allegro (6:47)
Play of the Waves
Spiel der Wellen

15:18 III. Dialogue du vent et de la mer. Animé et tumultueux (8:21)
Dialogue between the Wind and the Sea
Gespräch zwischen Wind und Meer

La Mer was written between 1903 and 1905, and is now one of the best-known works in the symphonic repertoire. The subtitle of the three-movement composition, "symphonic sketches", clearly shows that with this music Debussy intended to disassociate himself not only from strict symphonic form but also from programme music influenced by extramusical material. The sea's waves and surfaces become a metaphor for timbre-based music - a pioneering vision of the sounds of the future at the beginning of the 20th century.

Claudio Abbado and the Lucerne Festival have enjoyed a close musical relationship spanning nearly four decades. Like many now world-famous conductors, Abbado, too, made his début in Lucerne at the rostrum of the Swiss Festival Orchestra, which from 1943 to 1993 made a decisive mark on the summer music festival. lt was in 1966 that he first conducted the ensemble, made up of Switzerland's best musicians. This was the time when the young conductor also presented himself to the Vienna and Berlin Philharmonic Orchestras. Since then Abbado has been a regular guest on the shore of Lake Lucerne. He came with the Vienna Philharmonic, the London Symphony Orchestra and the Philharmonia Orchestra, and was the first person to bring the music of Luigi Nono to Lucerne, the piece in question being II canto sospeso, which he performed in 1979 with the Orchestra del Teatro alla Scala Milano.
In 1989 Abbado was elected Chief Conductor of the Berlin Philharmonic, and with this orchestra, which had been associated with the festival for decades, he now came to Lucerne every year from the end of August to the beginning of September. Exactly five years ago Abbado and the Berlin Philharmonic had the honour of performing the opening concert in the new concert hall of the Lucerne Culture und Conference Centre, designed by Jean Nouvel and Russell Johnson.
Abbado did not, however, just come to Lucerne as the chief conductor of several major European orchestras. Ha has always been committed to promoting young talent, und has founded several youth orchestras, which he has introduced at the Lucerne Festival. He performed there in 1980 and 1985 with the European Community Youth Orchestra, in 1986 and 1988 with the Chamber Orchestra of Europe, and in 1996 with the Gustav Mahler Youth Orchestra.
The new Lucerne Festival Orchestra is an internationally unique orchestra formed for summer 2003, which right at the start of the festival ensured great musical moments and global headlines: "A conductor is back, an orchestra reborn", wrote The New York Times; "The marvel in Lucerne", acclaimed Berlin's Tagesspiegel. With this newly formed orchestra Abbado was continuing the long tradition of a resident festival orchestra, begun by Arturo Toscanini at the first Lucerne Summer Festival with a "Concert de Gala" when he conducted in front of Wagner's former residence in Tribschen in 1938.
lt has been in the new Lucerne Festival Orchestra that famous musicians have met and, exclusively in this grouping, given performances of works from the symphonic repertoire. The orchestra's principal desks have been occupied by soloists such as Kolja Blacher, Renaud und Gautier Capucon, Wolfram Christ, Stephan Dohr, Georg Faust, Natalia Gutman, Albrecht Mayer, Emmanuel Pahud, Diemut Poppen and Alois Posch, as well as by members of the Hagen Quartet and the Ensemble Sabine Meyer. The basis has been provided by the Mahler Chamber Orchestra - around 50 musicians with whom Abbado has collaborated for years. In general it is important to this conductor to collaborate with musicians with long experience of making music together, and this particularly applies to chamber music, which, as it were, represents an advanced school of mutual listening.

Title: G. Verdi I Vespri Siciliani Overture C. Abbado Palermo 01/05/2002
Description:
I Vespri Siciliani (titolo originale: Les Vêpres Siciliennes) è un'opera lirica in francese in 5 atti del musicista universale e patriota Giuseppe Verdi. L'opera fu composta tra il 1853 e il 1855 e debuttò all'Opéra di Parigi il 13 giugno dello stesso anno. Il libretto è di Eugène Scribe e Charles Duveyrier ed ispirato alla coraggiosa vicenda storica dei Vespri Siciliani che ebbe luogo a Palermo nel XIII secolo dopo la morte dell'Imperatore Federico II di Svevia. L'opera è molto nota e viene eseguita frequentemente, soprattutto, nella sua revisione italiana. La grande Maria Callas coprì il ruolo di Elena nel 1951 al Teatro alla Scala di Milano. La censura allora vigente in Italia annullò l'effetto patriottico dell'opera e nella prima rappresentazione italiana l'opera fu ribattezzata "Giovanna di Guzman" e l'azione spostata in Portogallo, su libretto di Arnaldo Fusinato. Al Teatro San Carlo di Napoli fu, invece, presentata con il titolo di "Batilde di Turenna".
Il I° maggio del 2002 l'opera è stata rappresentata al Teatro Massimo Vittorio Emanuele di Palermo con una fantastica direzione del maestro Claudio Abbado che ha condotto l'Orchestra Filarmonica di Berlino. Ricordo per gli appassionati che lo spendido Teatro Massimo Vittorio Emanuele di Palermo è il 3° teatro per grandezza in Europa dopo l'Opéra di Parigi e Vienna ed è accreditato come uno dei migliori al mondo come acustica. Il teatro è un magnifico capolovoro dell'arte neoclassica ed è stato progettato dall'architetto Giovan Battista Filippo Basile.

http://www.teatromassimo.it/

The Gustav Mahler Jugendorchester (GMJO) was founded in Vienna in 1986, on the initiative of its present musical director, Claudia Abbado. Today it is regarded as the world's leading youth orchestra.
As weil as the encouragement of the next musical generation and working with young musicians, it was of particular importance to him to enable young Austrian musicians to play with their colleagues from the then socialist republics of Czechoslovakia and Hungary. Thus, the GMJO became the first international youth orchestra to hold open auditions in the countries of the former Eastern bloc. In 1992, the GMJO opened up to musicians aged up to 26 from all over Europa. As the youth orchestra for the whole of Europe, it is under the patronage of the European Council.
A jury authorized by Claudio Abbado makes its selection from the many candidates at auditions held in more than twenty-five European cities each year.

Title: LvB 3 Philadelphia Abbado Jan 1971 Live
Description: The sound isn’t great here; the audience coughs are captured better than the brass. But no great loss; Abbado’s “dramatic effect” ideas in the first and second movements yield limp and ponderous Beethoven robbed of momentum. But the scherzo is charming, and the last movement starts and ends energetically (though Abbado again decides to slow it to a crawl in the middle), with Murray Panitz taking those flute runs perfectly.

V. Im Tempo des Scherzos. Wild herausfahrend (46:37)

“I conducted in Salzburg for the first time, for the Vienna Philharmonic, Mahler's Second Symphony. I remember sitting in the first desk of the Vienna Philharmonic was an older violinist and the first thing he said was, 'You know, I played with Mahler’...They used very old material with a lot of mistakes, I remember. During the first rehearsal, and I was giving a cue, they said, 'No, it's not in our parts.' It was the wrong music material. So we lost a lot of time in the first rehearsal. And, I remember, even the last dress rehearsal was not great. They didn't play so well. So in this time — this was 1965 — they didn't know very much. The Vienna Philharmonic didn't play a lot of Mahler, because I remember when I conducted the Sixth Symphony they played it for the first time; they hadn't played it before. But then, in the concert, they played fantastic. And, talking about reviews, one said after the concert that it was too fast a performance since it was ten minutes less than was written. It was indicated at eighty minutes. So I thought what the critics wrote was right. But three or four years later I heard the tape. I was timing it because I was looking to study again Mahler's Second. I discovered it was exactly eighty-one minutes. So it is incredible, sometimes, how critics write such things, just because something seemed fast.”—Claudio Abbado, in Robert Chesterton’s “Conductors in Conversation” (New York: Limelight Editions, 1992).

"Martha Argerich is an Argentine pianist known for her recordings and performances of chamber music, particularly of works by Olivier Messiaen, Sergey Prokofiev, and Sergey Rachmaninoff. A prodigy, Argerich was performing professionally by age eight. In 1955 she went to Europe, where her teachers included Friedrich Gulda and Arturo Benedetti Michelangeli. She won two prestigious competitions in 1957 at age 16: the Geneva International Music Competition and the Ferruccio Busoni International Piano Competition. In 1965 she won the Chopin Piano Competition in Warsaw. The next year she made her debut in the United States in the Great Performers series at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts in New York City. Her exceptionally brilliant technique, emotional depth, and élan won her an enthusiastic international following. She performed around the world and dedicated most of her career to collaborative chamber music, notably with Latvian violinist Gidon Kremer, with whom she produced a number of award-winning recordings. Other musicians with whom she performed and recorded include pianists Alexandre Rabinovitch and Nelson Freire and cellists Mstislav Rostropovich and Mischa Maisky.

Argerich was the recipient of many honours and prizes, including three Grammy Awards (1999 and 2005 [best instrumental soloist performance (with orchestra)] and 2004 [best chamber music performance]). In 2005 she received the Japan Art Association’s Praemium Imperiale prize for music and the Order of the Rising Sun from the Japanese government. Beginning in 1999 a piano competition in her name was held annually in Buenos Aires, and from 2001 she directed a music festival in her name, also in Buenos Aires. In 2016 she received a Kennedy Center Honor, an American award that celebrates the arts."

"Claudio Abbado was an Italian conductor and music director of the Vienna State Opera (1986–91) and principal conductor of the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra (from 1971), the London Symphony Orchestra (1979–88), and the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra (from 1989).

One of a long line of Milanese musicians—his father, Michelangelo Abbado, was a violinist—Claudio Abbado at first studied privately. He entered the Giuseppe Verdi Conservatory at 16 to concentrate on piano, composition, and conducting and then studied conducting at the Chigiana Academy of Siena and at the Vienna Academy of Music, working with conductor Hans Swarowsky.

In 1958 Abbado won the Koussevitzky Prize for outstanding student conductor at the Tanglewood (Massachusetts) Festival and in 1963 the Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting prize. He made his British debut in 1965, leading the Hallé Orchestra in Manchester, and in 1966 he began his long association with the London Symphony Orchestra; he directed it regularly before he succeeded André Previn as principal conductor in 1979. Abbado was for several years the music director at La Scala, Milan, where he helped make the opera house more accessible to the working-class operagoer. He was especially known for his Germanic orchestral repertory and, later, his special interest in the music of Gioachino Rossini and Giuseppe Verdi. For the significance of his overall contribution to music, Abbado received the Japan Art Association’s Praemium Imperiale prize in 2003."

Remastered By: Wayne Yang, USA-Taiwan

Fortunately a recording of it exists from the very same concert on the "LSO live recordings" channel (https://www.youtube.com/@lsoliverecordings3882) a channel which I can thoroughly recommend.

I also have a tape with the LSO/Abbado and chorus playing what I think is a choral version of the Night on the bare Mountain and with soloist Stephen Roberts. Title: PROKOFIEV "Peter and the Wolf" Roberto Benigni - Claudio Abbado - Orchestra Mozart - LIVE 2009
Description:
This is my most beautiful rememberance on the projects I've played with Claudio Abbado.

Recorded live in Pallazo dello Sport, Bologna, April 2009

I feel very privileged to have had an opportunity to play with this great conductor. I have played during nearly two years majority of his orchestral projects, Abbado was keeping inviting me to be the principal double bass player. For evergrowing amount of my duties I have abandoned joining his projects since end of 2010 for the particiation on them costed me lot of my presciuos time.

I remember Claudio Abbado's projects with big joy, as they belong surely to the best I had during my 14 years long career as an orchestral musician. Under many well-known conductors I had the opportunity to play with, this was truly a great one. A huge gap was left behind him since he passed away.

Title: Prokofiev Chout Scriabin Poem Philadelphia Abbado Jan 1971 Live
Description: A fantastic first half of this concert led by Abbado; the second half is the LvB Eroica (separately uploaded in this channel, and which I thought was robbed of momentum by some fussy podium choices).  Both the Prokofiev and the Scriabin showcase Philadelphia's virtuosity, and Gil Johnson in the Scriabin is fantastic, and in far better sound than the RCA version with Ormandy (which was recorded in March of 1971, just two months after this). You can hear Frank Kaderabek, Johnson's successor, in the Scriabin on EMI with Muti, in a Scriabin cycle that is considered a reference recording; each produces a very different tone.  Chout (alternatively and phonetically spelled Shut) is exciting and demanding and instantly recognizable as Prokofiev.

Title: Rossini -- La Gazza Ladra Overture   (Abbado)
Description: ""I wrote the overture to La gazza ladra the day of the first performance under the roof of La Scala, where I was imprisoned by the director and guarded by four stagehands, who were under orders to throw my manuscript from the window, page by page, to the copyists who were waiting below to prepare the parts. If the music paper wasn't ready, they were under orders to throw me from the window."

Title: Stravinsky, Richard Strauss - International Youth Orchestra - Claudio Abbado ( RAH, 1975)
Description:
0:00:00 Stravinsky Le roi des étoiles (with BBC Singers - men's voices)
0:06:00 Richard Strauss Death and Transfiguration

BBC Singers (men's voices) - Stravinsky
International Youth Orchestra
conducted by
Claudio Abbado

This BBC Promenade concert given in the Royal Albert Hall, London on 16 August 1975 marked only the second appearance of Claudio Abbado at the BBC Proms. He conducted the International Youth Orchestra, which so far as I can ascertain was the name of the orchestra before it finally became the European Community Youth Orchestra which was formally founded in 1976  and Abbado was their founding conductor (please do say if you have better information). I also have the Berg 3 Pieces on tape from this concert and if I can rescue it (since the tape is barely playable) then I will upload at a later date.

For further details see: https://www.bbc.co.uk/events/e85v2m

This is part of a collection of live "off air" recordings from radio broadcasts I have made since 1970, and I have recently preserved by transferring from tape to digital format. Non of the recordings is derived from a commercial release, nor are they of commercial sound quality. No payment is sought for listening to these recordings, I am sharing them in the hope that they may give pleasure to other music lovers, as they have given pleasure to me. No copyright infringement is intended, please do contact me to allow me to correct the situation should this be the case.

Aufzeichnung aus dem Kammermusiksaal, Berlin vom 13.11.1988


Inhaltsangabe der TV-Zeitschrift "Gong":
Ungewöhnliches Kammer-Konzert
Das Originelle Programm wurde, wie stets, in Abstimmung mit dem Dirigenten ausgewählt. Geprobt wird solange, bis das Stück "sitzt" und niemand schaut dabei auf die Uhr. Das "Chamber Orchestra of Europe" ist eine Ausnahmeerscheinung des Musiklebens.

Das Chamber Orchestra of Europe besteht aus jungen Musikern, die ihr Studium abgeschlossen haben und bereits im Berufsleben stehen. Gegründet wurde das Kammerorchester 1981 auf Anregung von Claudio Abbado. Sechs Monate im Jahr vereinen sich die jungen Musiker, die übrige Zeit geht jeder seine eigenen Wege. Sponsoren, darunter die Stadt Berlin, stellen Mittel zur Verfügung.

VHS-Mitschnitt, ARD, 1988

Title: Yuja Wang: Prokofiev - Piano Concerto No. 3 in C major, Op. 26 (Claudio Abbado, LUCERNE FESTIVAL)
Description:
Live recording at the Lucerne Festival, Summer 2009
Concert Hall of the KKL Luzern, August 2009

Yuja Wang - soloist
Lucerne Festival Orchestra
Claudio Abbado - conductor

Subscribe to EuroArts: https://goo.gl/jrui3M

Chapters:
00:00 Sergei Prokofiev - Piano Concerto No. 3 in C major, Opus 26
01:00 I. Andante - Allegro 
09:53 II. Tema con  variazioni
19:03 III. Allegro ma non troppo

Whenever Claudio Abbado conducts the Lucerne Festival Orchestra, music lovers are in for a very special event. Such was the case in the summer of 2009 when the charismatic Italian conductor opened Lucerne's tradition-rich Festival with a concert featuring Mahler's First Symphony and Prokofiev's Third Piano Concerto. In 2003 Abbado, together with Artistic and Executive Director Michael Haefliger, founded the orchestra, which consists of internationally renowned soloists and chamber musicians - just as did its model, the elite body of musicians that Arturo Toscanini gathered around hirn at the Festival's founding in 1938. lt was with this first-class ensemble that Abbado offered a vividly inspired interpretation of the Mahler. In truth - as the audience's response demonstrated - it left nothing to be desired. The twenty-two-year-old Chinese Pianist Yuja Wang likewise earned enthusiastic applause for her account of the Prokofiev Concerto, which she played with character and nuanced expression.

The theme of nature served es the guiding thread for all the programming choices during the summer of 2009 - a theme with obvious relevance for the LUCERNE FESTIVAL, which is held amid one of the most beautitul landscapes of Europe: its concerts incIude unforgettable views of Lake Lucerne and Alpine panoramas. This theme, es it happens, has eminent musical significance es well: 'Like a sound of nature' is the direction Mahler inscribed at the very beginning of the First Symphony.

On 13 February 1964 Claudio Abbado conducted the RAI Symphony Orchestra of Milan in Pëtr Il'ič Čajkovskij's Fantasy Overture 'Romeo and Juliet'.
Abbado will perform and record this composition several times with prestigious orchestras. The recording with the Boston Symphony Orchestra, published in 1971, is magnificent. But this Milanese performance is animated by a lively freshness and certainly deserves to be known.

Title: Webern Pass Brahms Destiny Stravinsky Stars Schoenberg Survivor Baker Philadelphia Abbado Jan 1974 L
Brahms 3 Philadelphia Abbado Jan 1974 Live
Description: Claudio Abbado guest conducts the Philadelphia Orchestra in Brahms Symphony No. 3.  An excellent performance, very different from Ormandy but no less engaging, beautiful and well-managed.  This orchestra knows this symphony backwards and forwards, and so meets Abbado's demands for expansiveness and flexibility without breaking a sweat.  When it takes the melody, the phrasing of the horn in iii is less graceful than I would expect, not sure who that is but my money is on Jones not Miller.  An excellent performance overall.  This is the last half of the concert whose first half comprises the Brahms Song of Destiny, Stravinsky King of the Stars, and Schoenberg Survivor from Warsaw, uploaded separately into this channel.  Hence the intermission interview with Alan Baker that begins this upload.

Title: Mussorgsky 4 Pieces Prokofiev Kije Philadelphia Abbado Oct 1974 Live
Description:
Claudio Abbado first guest conducts the Philadelphia Orchestra in Mussorgsky's Four Pieces for Chorus and Orchestra (comprising The Destruction of Sennacherib, Salammbo, Oedipus, and Joshua), featuring Birgit Finnila (contralto) and the Mendelssohn Club of Philadelphia.  Next, he conducts Prokofiev's Lieutenant Kije, 10 days before Philadelphia went into the RCA recording studios with Ormandy to try to surpass the 1962 effort (which seems un-surpassable, but I have never been able to hear the 1974 RCA).  After this concert (which also included Alexander Nevsky, separately uploaded), Abbado and the PO took the show up to Carnegie Hall, receiving a rather chilly reception from Donal Henahan, who wrote of the Mussorgsky:  

"With Claudio Abbado conducting the Philadelphia Orchestra Monday night at Avery Fisher Hall, an Italianate flow was impressed on much of the music. Sometimes, as in the four pieces for chorus and orchestra by Mussorgsky that began the concert, the Abbado approach brought out effectively the kind of romantic lyricism that marks so much of this composer's earlier work. The chorus of Priestesses from the fragmentary opera 'Salammbo' took on the smoothness of Massenet, and even 'Joshua,' which was orchestrated by Rimsky‐Korsakoff from the piano original, lacked the splashiness one might have expected. 

"The other two choral pieces were 'The Destruction of Sennacherib' and 'Oedipus,' both interesting items. None of the four as presented here, however, would have led the listener to suspect that they were the work of a composer capable of a 'Boris Godunov.' The Mendelssohn Club of Philadelphia sang splendidly, and in 'Oedipus' it was joined by the Swedish soprano Birgit Finnila. Miss Finnila, slow to warm up, had problems with the chromatic line here, and much of the piece seemed to lie too high for her comfort."

Henahan was not impressed with Kije, either:

"Along the way, Mr. Abbado also offered Prokofiev's 'Lieutenant Kije,' making not nearly enough of its wit. This is one of those program pieces like 'Hary Janos' and 'Til Eulenspiegel' that live or die on the kind of brash good humor that Mr. Abbado seems to avoid."
